conclusion: We have an ideal gas being heated gradually with p-T and V-T graphs provided.
Ideal gas laws like Charles's Law and Gay-Lussac's Law relate pressure, volume, and temperature.
p-T graph shows a straight line from 0.5 × 10^5 Pa at 200 K to 1.0 × 10^5 Pa at 400 K.
Pressure increases linearly with temperature, suggesting Gay-Lussac's Law: p ∝ T.
V-T graph shows a horizontal line from 400 K to 600 K with constant volume at 2 m³.
V-T graph shows volume increases linearly from 2 m³ to 3 m³ from 600 K to 700 K.
Temperature axis ranges from 0 to 700 K with markings every 100 K.
p-T graph has data points at 200 K and 400 K; V-T graph at 400 K, 600 K, and 700 K.
Determine pressure at 600 K using the p-T graph.
Calculate slope of p-T line: m = 2500 Pa/K.
Equation of line: p = mT + b; calculate b using point (200 K, 0.5 × 10^5 Pa).
Calculation error identified in determining b.
Recalculate slope: m = 2500 Pa/K, verify calculation.
Consider using ideal gas law pV = nRT due to constant volume.
